reviewText: Long before the Rat Pack and the Brat Pack and the Baby Boomers and the Gen Xers, there was Our Gang. The spunky team of wee ones included Spanky, Alfalfa, Buckwheat, Froggy, Butch, Darla and a host of other human and canine (think Pete the Dog and Violet the Goat)oddities.There's even little Mickey Guibitosi, who would later change his name to Robert Blake, and later, to inmate No. 7253166.Originally developed by producer Hal Roach as a series of silent shorts, Our Gang remained a box-office favorite for decades, pulling in name recognition (and tarnished futures) for the kids and big bucks for distributor MGM.In the mid-1950s, the Roach-produced shorts with sound were syndicated for television under the title The Little Rascals, as MGM retained the rights to the Our Gang trademark.When Roach decided to cease production of the series in mid-1938, MGM took over, keeping the little rascals responsible for the endless popularity of the shorts. Now Warner Brothers Video is thrusting the crowd into the spotlight once again, this time as part of a five-disc set containing all 52 of the Our Gang shorts produced between 1938 and 1944. They are presented here in chronological order, beginning with "The Little Ranger" from 1938 and ending with "Tale of a Dog" from 1944.But oh! The racism! So much so that the set contains a warning (!) from  Warner Bros. Video: "The Our Gang Collection is intended for the adult collector and is not suitable for children."Witness: "Men in Fright," in which the kids visit Darla at the hospital after she's had her tonsils removed. The poor gal can't eat any food, so the wieners, ice cream and other goodies are scuffed down by her pals. And pal Buckwheat sucks down one thing: watermelon. He spots it, his eyes bulge and he inhales it down to the rind.Witness: "Captain Spanky's Showboat," in which Buckwheat, gnawing on an animal leg, plays Oogie Boogie, The Wild Man of Borneo, a "homage" to "The Kid From Boreno" (1933), one of the most notoriously racist Our Gang shorts.More proof that Warner Home Video will do anything to make a buck.BUY MY NEW BOOKMorbid Curiosity: The Disturbing Demises of the Famous and Infamous
summary: SUCH LITTLE RASCALS! SUCH SILLINESS! SUCH RACISM! SUCH A DATED GANG.
Title: N/A

reviewText: My friends, we all know that these OUR GANG comedies (made after the great Hal Roach heyday of 1922-1938) are not up to the original series. Much of it in fact (such as 123 GO, Don't Lie, Doin' Our Bit, and Benjamin Franklin Jr) predated the PC killjoy message oriented kid's "entertainment" of recent times.With that said, some of these are in fact quite amusing and have their moments. "Aladdin's Lantern" is a funny backstage tale. "Unexpected Riches" has a pretty fascinating (if un-PC by modern standards) scene of Buckwheat, rich form his share of buried treasure, parading through a Black neighborhood joyfully sahring his fortune with the town. "Clown Princes" is a good circus story(the lemonade gag will guarantee guffaws). "Mighty Like a Goat" is a humorous outing of the gang's encounter with a skunk. "Tale of a Dog," the very last Our Gang comedy ever made, gives the series a pretty fond farewell as the townspeople mistakenly assume that the black kids (Buckwheat and Big Shot) are purposely spreading smallpox in their town (trust me, not as vicious as it sounds).OK if bought used.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The big news this month is that SPANKY, ALFALFA, BUCKWHEAT, DARLA, and the rest of their pals take the spotlight in the OUR GANG COLLECTION. Originally developed by producer Hal Roach as a series of silent short subjects, OUR GANG remained a box office favorite for decades creating healthy profits for their distributor MGM.When Roach decided to cease production of the series in mid-1938, MGM took over production, retaining the kid star favorites responsible for the endless popularity of the shorts.This new 5 disc set contains all 52 of the Our Gang shorts produced by MGM between 1938 and 1944, in their original uncut form as first seen in theaters. Among the titles are PARTY FEVER, THE LITTLE RANGER, ALFALFA'S AUNT, DON'T LIE and dozens more. Also seen in the cast are FROGGY, PORKY, and even little Mickey Guibitosi, who soon changed his screen name to Bobby (Robert) Blake.This collection marks the first-ever home video release of the entire group of the 52 MGM shorts, news sure to be welcome by the horde of Our Gang fans far and wide. The Our Gang comedies are the first in a series of monthly Warner Archive Collection releases to be drawn from the Warner library of classic theatrical short subjects originally produced by both Warner Bros. and MGM.Go to: WBshop.com - The Official Online Store of Warner Bros. for the lowest prices
summary: AVAILABLE FOR $34.95 DIRECTLY FROM WARNER BROTHERS SHOP ONLINE

reviewText: Although there are many who would disagree with me, I couldn't stop watching The Our Gang Collection without an occasional chuckle while taking my stroll down memory road.  They may not be laugh-out-loud funny like the Hal Roach shorts, but it is still a relevant collection that won't disappoint a true fan.  Yes, I know all about the parental warning on the box and the vicious controversy surrounding this release, but the fact remains that the antics portrayed by Spanky, Alphafa, Darla and Buckwheat are a part of American history we cannot erase.  Racism in our culture existed whether we approved of it or not, particularly in the year 1938.  While I haven't yet watched all 52 episodes, I did note scenes that qualify for an explanation if one is watching the collection with children, especially for the racist portrayal of Buckwheat which I was happy to explain to my own children in a way that only a parent can.  I know the 52 shorts are no where as funny and but there is something wonderfully nostalgic found in the Warner Archive Collection and any true Our Gang Club fan will want to include this set in their video library.
summary: Let go of the Hal Roach version and sit back and laugh
Title: N/A

reviewText: Do not confuse the 52 Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer shorts with the classic comedies produced by Hal Roach Studios. When Roach sold Our Gang to MGM in 1938, the creative spark quickly diminished until the series became unwatchable. Apart from the initial 1938-39 shorts (highlighted by "The Little Ranger," "Aladdin's Lantern," "Men in Fright" and "Alfalfa's Aunt"), these one-reel travesties lack the charm and spontaneity of the Roach efforts. Spanky, Buckwheat and the gang were badly served by MGM's joyless, heavy-handed approach. On the plus side, the DVD set features excellent and uncut 35mm prints - which cannot be said for the sloppy RHI/Genius "Little Rascals" collection.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The "Our Gang" series can hardly be slandered as 'racist'.I will ask at the outset that all references to 'Black' or 'Blacks' be understood as retaining my full respect. It's usage appears to have become unpopular lately in some circles, but I don't think Eldridge Cleaver or his historical contemporaries would find it insulting, certainly not as much as 'Negro' or 'Colored' nor is it as conspicuously neutral and bland as 'People of Color'.First of all, the number of stereotypical Black gags within the series are minimal - only five percent of the episodes use even one gag in a film and it usually has something to do with the kids love of watermelon or napping, which all the kids of "Our Gang" indulge in. Hardly hate-filled and offensive.Second, Farina, Stymie and Buckwheat are often portrayed as much wiser and more sensible than their caucasian friends. Farina in particular is frequently in a role of responsibility, a role he attempts to fill admirably if also comically. This is an inherently positive and sympathetic portrayal.Third, at no time in the over ninety episodes I've viewed does any member of the "Gang" treat Farina, Stymie or Buckwheat as less than a full friend, nor is any difference in race mocked nor exploited. In fact, I don't think the difference is ever mentioned. Often, however, traditionally Black occupational roles that were common at the time the series was produced are assigned to the Black kids, such as usher at the many 'follies' the kids performed, but the series was not intended to be a consciousness-raiser and so they are not given leading positions within the context of the plots. To have done so would have been highly conspicuous and a provocation to potentially intolerant Whites; the series was designed for mass consumption, after all.As for classic episodes like "The Kid from Borneo", characters like 'Uncle George' are played absurdly and not as a caricature of modern African-Americans but of South Sea natives. These shorts being pre-war and Americans of that time considerably less informed and worldly, 'Uncle George' may be forgiven. I don't believe the color of his skin makes any difference here: the character could just as easily been Inuit, just so long as his origin was exotic to Americans of the mid-1930s.The "Our Gang" series of short films as shown in syndication probably did more to overcome prejudice in youngsters growing up in the years 1950 through 1990 than any other children's program besides those on public television, and that only available since 1968. I may claim this with impunity because the evidence is clear - America is less racist now and better informed regarding 'how the other half lives' than they were previously and that was not simply due to books like "Soul On Ice" and the actions of Dr. Martin Luther King. The seeds of tolerance and understanding were planted much earlier in those who would listen - and watch.A brief review of the shorts that were banned from TV such as "A Tough Winter" reveal that the main 'objectionable' element in them is that they are primarily about the Black kids. With the exception of "Amos and Andy" and the appearance of 'Rochester' on Jack Benny's show, Black performers were not welcome on television until the producers of shows featuring Bill Cosby and Flip Wilson took advantage of the new consciousness that came about when the Baby Boomers came of age. That is to say, the "Our Gang" shorts were not censored or withheld because some of the gags were racist, but primarily because the appearance of Black children, their on-screen time infrequently but occasionally out of proportion to the rest of the caucasian "Our Gang" cast, was not considered or believed to be considered welcome in 1950's American households. This indicates the tremendous influence television programmers have over public perception of social issues.In any current dialogue regarding race and racial social issues the nationality of those speaking will be of concern. That is to say, that a caucasian with an opinion on the experience of the African American community will be scoffed at. This is the final impediment to a real and honest dialogue. No one can live anothers life or see the world, in fact, through another eyes. But so long as there is imagination and empathy a degree of understanding may be achieved.There is no human experience that may not be understood and appreciated.I have not formed my opinions soley on the basis of my own preferences but through years of listening and speaking with Black friends and acquaintances - some of them strangers with no reason to soft-peddle their own strong opinions to me. I've discussed the "Little Rascals" frequently. Never once have I heard any of them claim, whether young nor old, that the "Our Gang" series of theatrical shorts was offensive to them in a racist context. In fact, I recall my shock and partial embarassment when one fellow brought up how funny he thought it was that the talcum powder used on Farina's brother was coal dust!Where there is no hateful or disrespectful intent, their is no racism, or at least none to be concerned about. That is, there is a line and difference between 'racist' and 'racially aware', but the majority of gags in "Our Gang" perceived as 'racist' are actually of cultural concern regarding African Americans.I find the word 'racism' is used in a contemporary context that encompasses a negative attitude rather than a mere fact of birth, and it is in this sense that I find no racism, as it is commonly understood today, in the "our Gang" comedies.Differences exist between Americans, we cannot ignore them nor wish them away nor should we. It would be a mistake to render ourselves utterly homogeneous, rather we should strive to maintain the "rainbow of diversity" and celebrate the differences, and celebration must include humor.The "Our Gang" series playfully, warm-heartedly and good-naturedly poked fun at many ethnicities and social strata. If the gags dealing with the Black kids stand in sharp relief to the others in the modern American mind truly, it is only due to the color of their skin.
Title: N/A
